I thought I was going to ask Ernie to marry me in Tokyo, but I'm no longer as spontaneous as I once was. I don't particularly mind not having his ring on my finger; I think I've snared him fairly well without it. :) We had a few strange conversations, and I'm still sorting out some of the things I said. Sometimes I wonder at my forgetfulness, my tunnel vision, when it comes to my loved ones. Ernie's not an honest man, and I know that. But on a deeper level, an emotional one, he's the truest one I know. His heart's all leopardskin and jewels -isn't that how I described it?- and there's nothing hidden under them. I also spoke to Professor Matsushita about my Genji work, and she has offered to collaborate with me. I am not sure how I feel about this opportunity. It would feel good to give over what I've done to her -she's assured me of collaborator credit, either way- but I'm attached to my choices, even if some of them were wrong. I suppose now is the time to decide whether this is a vanity project or a real endeavor. If I stopped now, I'd have to find something else to work on with my spare time, my time that I set aside for real thinking. Working on this translation challenges me in a way that nothing else does. If I were to work on it seriously, or finish it, it might lose its fun. I shouldn't have written her back. I've missed my Chinatsu so much. I've got her room all ready, and I can't wait to hear her news. She was so tall, over Christmas break! It's as if she's trying to match the British children...she'll tower over me, I'm sure. I wonder if she'll have an accent now? Being all alone here has made me feel like Japanese is my own private language, or a private voice for the two of us. Going back to Tokyo was almost like going back into a dream.

This is IceToad-- first name Ice, surname Toad. He is a taciturn, brooding, facially tattooed man who enjoys suffering, hurting people, and standing in the rain. Ice's primary weapon is the pie gun. His parents, bakers both, taught him to make the finest pies in MagiBattleVille; unfortunately the young Ice was ridiculed by the youthful peers who didn't understand his passion for pastry. This eventually drove him to a life of crime, first robbery, then murder. Always he would leave pie at the scene, partly as a calling card, but mostly to assuage his guilt with the good feeling of feeding a hungry policeman. 

One fateful night, Ice was fleeing the Aurors through a church when he was unexpectedly given sanctuary by the kindly priest. The two became close friends, and Ice experienced, if not a conversion, at least an epiphany. One morning, after a long stay at the church, he mounted his Nimbus 2000 and rode away without a glance back at his benefactor. He was, once more, ready for action. This time, however, Ice had a better cause: he would distribute his fine pies, not to compensate for his evil, but solely to do good.

Unfortunately the world into which Ice stepped was full of people beating the hell out of each other, and after one or two sound drubbings, he fled back into the arms of violence. What can I say? Easy come, easy go.

I am walking through Shibuya after dark. Everything is strangely blurry; it looks almost pixellated, and it is all in black and white. People walk by slowly. They are white and blurred and their feet are not properly touching the ground.

I am trying to go to the store for a bottle of water, but I'm wearing a big, heavy rucksack which is hung all over with metal scourges. Every time I take a step, the scourges bump and bite into my arms and legs. I remove the pack, although the scourges turn into little suckers and they put up a tremendous fight. I walk warily backwards, holding my wand, because the pack is starting to regain its strength and it is beginning to walk on the suckers as if they were insect legs. I can move much faster, though, and I run to the store.

When I get there, I find that it is closed, and the pixellated doors tingle and burn when I touch them. I blast them open with my wand and they singe like paper. Inside everything is halftone and still, the shoppers frozen in attitutes of everyday life. As I get further into the store, it looks less halftone and more charred, and puffs of charcoal are stirred up by my feet and cling to my unshaven legs. The water is at the very back and the bottles are all melted. I have to push aside a blackened, skeletal little hand to get at the best-preserved one.

Then I am wandering through the store, trying to find the exit again. I take a wrong turn and then I'm in an orchard, a grove of orange trees. I take a deep breath, but it's silent and they don't smell of anything.

Eleanor, 6. Sweet but demanding, spoiled in that way that some little girls can be-- automatically, even if raised in an orphanage. Talkative. Overeducated, and probably the kind of juvenile mythologist who doesn't know reality from fiction. Very familiar, of course, because I was once a bright child too. And so was Ernie, in his way. I see only a little of him in her, but it's enough. Roland (Rollie), 10. Quiet and clever. The more immediately likable of the two, though this is entirely a function of their ages. Interested in insects, and will probably cry if he isn't sorted into Hufflepuff. Fortunately, this seems quite unlikely. He was extremely nice to Chinatsu, and doesn't seem to think much of himself. Is that from his father...? I don't tend to date self-confident men, but Ernie is the eternal exception. No. Ernie knows himself well, after all. But he might once have been like either of them. I want to meet their mother. I will in passing, if at all. I want to know what kind of parent she is. She seems to encourage their passions, and she certainly dresses them well (if Ernie didn't have them in the morning, anyway) but I have never gotten a very good idea from him of what she's like. It's not his fault. I just don't ask enough.

She even seems happy to be! We're going out shopping in a few minutes. I missed shopping with my girl; she can always find the most interestingly fluffy things. And tonight we're all having dinner at my house, so I have to pick up the crabmeat...I'm making sushi! Well, rolls, anyway. And nothing scarier than smoked salmon. I can't guarantee our survival if I take a greater risk. I'm not doing anything today except cook, clean and buy clothes. My day couldn't get any more female unless I was actually giving birth. Fortunately, that is not on the schedule; I would have had to pencil it into lunchtime, and if it took more than two hours we wouldn't have time to do the laundry or alter anything. ...Chinatsu, wake up. I don't have any library books left, and there's no day-trading on Easter weekend. Nobody's online, either, which makes sense at 8:43 a.m. on a weekend. But we both went to bed early. I know we did. Her light was off. I hope that everyone has a good Easter tomorrow. We don't have any particular plans, though I think that Chinatsu is going to a friend's for part of the day. Sometimes I forget that she's only fifteen, and sometimes I'm surprised that she's as old as fifteen. Is that just what happens with children? Or is age relative with everyone? Sometimes I feel much younger than I used to. Lighter, and less polished, and more funny, and gladder to be alive-- not that I was ever any of those things when I was younger. But I still remind myself of the way I was then, or the way I tried to act. Isn't that odd? I was pretending to be just what I am. Anyway, the days fill up just as they used to. I work more, and translate less, but I'm still doing the latter, every evening for an hour. I'm going through in order, now. I haven't thrown out my old drafts, but I can see flaws in their language; I've always had to work hard to understand the difference between English and Japanese speech patterns, and when I reread my old work I find that I'm not using either properly. Either they sound like English people or they sound like an eighteenth-century English speaker trying to explain how the Japanese talk. It all seems a much more daunting task than it once did. And much more of a task, much more the setting down of words on paper, with the implied duty of honesty to them. Then again, so many people are dishonest and fine. Junko gave me a copy of The Tale of Murasaki last week; it's all nonsense. We don't know enough about Murasaki to write a biography, much less a novel. But there is a good chapter in which she meets Shonagon, who is written just how I imagined her to be, and when I was reading it I wanted it to be true. In a way, I suspect fictionalization is the highest form of flattery. I don't think I would mind being written into a novel, myself, even if far less than a thousand years had gone by. It's the same with all of the books and movies and plays that have used elements from Genji over the years. A text evolves and is misused, and that's how we know that it is good. Maybe the ideal translation is highly edited, heavily rewritten and adapted to the speech patterns of its audience. Maybe pastiches should be read as part of the original. Maybe the authors of Bridget Jones' Diary and The Redoubtable Thomas should get more credit. But if that's the case, this isn't the task for me. I don't know how I would change this book, if I had the chance. I just know how it goes. Banana Yoshimoto wrote a novella (does she ever write anything else?) called NP. It was about a short story whose would-be translators all killed themselves, and incest. I should reread that. Here is Chinatsu! And she's wearing her crown!

One of them is small and hard, like a stone. It isn't impossible to penetrate, but one must posses a diamond. This is not a rough stone, but a carefully set and polished one; its bearer has obviously worked hard at keeping it looking like a candy, even though it sits on the dresser, largely forgotten otherwise.

One of them is big but strangely dry. It is still working, but it is leathery inside, like a seed or a nut which still rattles when shaken. It does not pull you in, but you can climb to the center without incident.

One of them is large but porous-- not unlike a jungle inside. The closer you get to the center, the more it pulls you towards your given place. Not everyone finds themselves in it immediately; most find themselves in it by accident. 

Yet another is blue and labyrinthine. You may enter it easily, but you may not leave without picking something up and putting something down. It is squelchier than the previous, and moves you through it with similar speed, but sometimes places you in another compartment rather than keeping you in the same.

Another is pale orange, and lined with all sorts of strange items-- green shag carpering, tiger fur, dark wood panelling, sandstone, stars. It can't be entered in company with another person. This heart is hung inside with pictures, like a museum, although there is no scuplture in the middle of the rooms. There are benches. You may stay as long as you like without paying admission.

The last one is smooth and cold, an underground cave made of rose quartz where children run and play on the floor. The children are allowed to play with chalk, but adults coming in are handed hoses and squirt guns instead. There is an amphitheater at the center, in which comedies and tragedies are constantly played out.

I will be using names. I've lost patience with trying to second-guess Murasaki-sensei; I'm staying with my most recent conclusion, that she did it to maintain the novel's atmosphere of gossip or furtive storytelling, the conceit of an attendant whispering to her lady about other court figures whose names she'd already know, with the secondary intention of showing characters' rising and falling status. Well, there are other ways to make that apparent. A thousand years' worth of audiences have spoken: the characters need names for this nightmarishly huge book to make sense, and they have accordingly given them some. I'm thinking of doing the Akashi/Akikonomu thread next, after I finish doing the Yugao short story. It's a large and significant section, and contains the best poetry in the book, and it will be hard going. Even so, I have enough interest in the Akashi character to make me think that she is the best inroad into the main plots. This is a recent development. I'd never even really noticed her before, but now that I start to mark off the various plots, whole new sides have begun to emerge. She's intelligent and composed, an excellent poet, and she knows herself better than any other character (except Kashiwagi, who just carries it too far). She sees right through Genji, yet she's been known to worry about her own status, and have her various insecurities as well. I'd like to know her. I'll settle for interpreting her.

I found the the last Seirei Reiko collection today, so I went ahead and found out how it ended. There are only so many ways to finish the story of a vengeful ghost and her tormentor's descendants, so I assumed it would be tragic- but I was not expecting the end of the world. I suppose that if you're going to kill every character the readers care about, you might as well go the rest of the way. I assumed that I would be disappointed by the ending -every story you abandon seems smaller when you return- but either Kaminaga has become a truly brilliant writer, or my expectations were too low, or both. Probably the latter. I don't blame myself; stories, as I said, do shrink, and the shopkeeper talked about Reiko in very nostalgic tones. "Will this someday be milked for nostalgia?" is a good question to ask of anything when you want to know if it will last. Although since the ending was good, I can only conclude that he was fooled by the faux-seventies art style. If I'd been paying attention, I probably could have objected to the description of a story dating from 1992-96 as "old" and then learned the truth. But at this point, I have the book and don't care any longer. From excessive Genji and Chinatsu to none at all! Ah, well. Next time.

And now, a person who knows his name: would you like me to come over again tonight-tomorrow? I'm still worried about you, and we didn't really talk...
All around you, every day, people are shrinking. If they seem to grow, it's only because they are dissolving into the air.
